nodes.text: Paul Dean : I welcome the arrangements that the Government have made
Asserting
Paul Dean welcomes the arrangements for new retirement pensioners during the Civil Service dispute that the Government have made
Ella : Paul Dean : I welcome the arrangements that the Government have made

Paul Dean : I ask my hon. Friend to give an assurance that new pensioners will be given the benefit of any doubt and that there will be no question of those likely to be entitled to pension having to apply for supplementary benefit
Assertive Questioning

Paul Dean asks Lynda Chalker to give an assurance that new pensioners will be given the benefit of any doubt and that there will be no question of those likely to be entitled to pension having to apply for supplementary benefit

Ella : Paul Dean : I ask my hon. Friend to give an assurance that new pensioners will be given the benefit of any doubt and that there will be no question of those likely to be entitled to pension having to apply for supplementary benefit
Default Transition
Lynda Chalker :  I am sure that I can give my hon. Friend that assurance
Ella : Lynda Chalker :  I am sure that I can give my hon. Friend that assurance
Default Transition
Agreeing
Ella : Lynda Chalker : before pension entitlement is fully 251 worked out
Ella : Lynda Chalker : there is any case of hardship or need
Ella : Lynda Chalker : I am quite sure that the local office will be able to help any pensioner in that predicament, perhaps through supplementary benefit, if other entitlements cannot be finalised
Lynda Chalker : before pension entitlement is fully 251 worked out, there is any case of hardship or need
Asserting
before pension entitlement is fully worked out, there is any case of hardship or need
Ella : Lynda Chalker : before pension entitlement is fully 251 worked out, there is any case of hardship or need
Default Transition
Lynda Chalker : the local office will be able to help any pensioner in that predicament, perhaps through supplementary benefit, if other entitlements cannot be finalised
Asserting
the local office will be able to help any pensioner in that predicament, perhaps through supplementary benefit, if other entitlements cannot be finalised
Ella : Lynda Chalker : the local office will be able to help any pensioner in that predicament, perhaps through supplementary benefit, if other entitlements cannot be finalised
Default Transition
Unknown Buchan : Is not there a stark contrast between the Government’s behaviour in this dispute and the behaviour of the civil servants
Assertive Questioning
there is a stark contrast between the Government’s behaviour in this dispute and the behaviour of the civil servants
Ella : Unknown Buchan : Is not there a stark contrast between the Government’s behaviour in this dispute and the behaviour of the civil servants
Default Transition
Unknown Buchan : Under extreme provocation and frustration, the civil servants have continued to ensure that the beneficiaries have been paid
Asserting
under extreme provocation and frustration, the civil servants have continued to ensure that the beneficiaries have been paid
Ella : Unknown Buchan : Under extreme provocation and frustration, the civil servants have continued to ensure that the beneficiaries have been paid
Unknown Buchan : the Government, who from the beginning knew that they intended to provoke and maintain a long-standing dispute, failed to take any measures to alert the beneficiaries
Asserting
the Government, who from the beginning knew that they intended to provoke and maintain a long-standing dispute, failed to take any measures to alert the beneficiaries
Ella : Unknown Buchan : the Government, who from the beginning knew that they intended to provoke and maintain a long-standing dispute, failed to take any measures to alert the beneficiaries
Default Inference
Default Transition
Default Conflict
Default Transition
Disagreeing
Unknown Buchan : It was left to us to involve even the CBI to help with the publicity
Asserting
it was left to us to involve even the CBI to help with the publicity
Ella : Unknown Buchan : It was left to us to involve even the CBI to help with the publicity
Default Transition
Unknown Buchan : That is disgraceful
Asserting
leaving it to us to involve CBI is disgraceful
Ella : Unknown Buchan : That is disgraceful

Unknown Buchan : Is not the best solution for the Government to drop their intransigence, to follow the lead that has been taken by the Civil Service, to settle the dispute, to give some justice back to the civil servants and to make sure that all beneficiaries are paid at the proper time and at the proper level
Assertive Questioning

it is the best solution for the Government to drop their intransigence, to follow the lead that has been taken by the Civil Service, to settle the dispute, to give some justice back to the civil servants and to make sure that all beneficiaries are paid at the proper time and at the proper level

Ella : Unknown Buchan : Is not the best solution for the Government to drop their intransigence, to follow the lead that has been taken by the Civil Service, to settle the dispute, to give some justice back to the civil servants and to make sure that all beneficiaries are paid at the proper time and at the proper level
Default Inference
Default Transition
Default Transition
Arguing

Ella : Lynda Chalker : The only way in which people who are vulnerable in society can be protected from the continuing industrial action is for civil servants to take up their grievances as they have always done in the past and not to withhold the payment of benefit through our computer centres

Lynda Chalker : The only way in which people who are vulnerable in society can be protected from the continuing industrial action is for civil servants to take up their grievances as they have always done in the past
Asserting

the only way in which people who are vulnerable in society can be protected from the continuing industrial action is for civil servants to take up their grievances as they have always done in the past

Ella : Lynda Chalker : The only way in which people who are vulnerable in society can be protected from the continuing industrial action is for civil servants to take up their grievances as they have always done in the past
Lynda Chalker : not to withhold the payment of benefit through our computer centres
Asserting
civil servants should not withhold the payment of benefit through our computer centres in industrial action
Ella : Lynda Chalker : not to withhold the payment of benefit through our computer centres
Default Transition
Default Inference
Default Transition
Arguing
Lynda Chalker : The hon. Gentleman knows perfectly well that extensive efforts have been made by my right hon. and hon. Friends at the Civil Service Department
Asserting
Unknown Buchan knows perfectly well that extensive efforts have been made by Lynda Chalker's right honourable and honourable Friends at the Civil Service Department
Ella : Lynda Chalker : The hon. Gentleman knows perfectly well that extensive efforts have been made by my right hon. and hon. Friends at the Civil Service Department
Default Transition
Lynda Chalker : Those efforts will continue and will bring this dispute to a successful resolution
Asserting
the efforts from those at the Civil Service Department will continue and will bring this dispute to a successful resolution
Ella : Lynda Chalker : Those efforts will continue and will bring this dispute to a successful resolution
Default Transition
Default Inference
Arguing
